thread.title: State of Origin 3: Trent Merrin, James Tamou, records among talking points | Video, highlights | State of Origin | NRL 2013 State of Origin - Blues vs Maroons
thread.title_full: State of Origin 3: Trent Merrin, James Tamou, records among talking points | Video, highlights | State of Origin | NRL 2013 State of Origin - Blues vs Maroons | The Advertiser

author: CAMERON TOMARCHIO
title: State of Origin 3: Trent Merrin, James Tamou, records among talking points | Video, highlights | State of Origin | NRL 2013 State of Origin - Blues vs Maroons
text:
EMBARRASSED and outclassed, NSW resorted to cheap shots as Queensland romped to a record 52-6 victory.
These were the big talking points.
1. JAMES TAMOU’S SHOT ON LILLYMAN
WITH Queensland heading towards the 40-point mark, James Tamou snapped, hitting Queensland’s Jacob Lillyman across the face with a straight arm.
It got dirtier still as Tamou put in an uppercut for good measure as Lillyman crashed to the turf.
He was placed on report and will miss one game if he takes the early plea after being charged with a grade one striking.
James Tamou followed this stiff arm with an upper cut on Jacob Lillyman. Source: Channel 9
2. MERRIN FLIPS PARKER ON HIS HEAD
BLUES forward Trent Merrin is facing a four-week stint after being charged with a grade two dangerous throw of Corey Parker.
Fortunately, Parker walked away without injury as Merrin upended the Broncos veteran.
Trent Hodkinson was the other man involved in the tackle but did not appear to be at fault.
Corey Parker is put in a scary position. Source: Getty Images
3. JT’S SUPER BOOT
NOT only did Johnathan Thurston boot a record nine goals from nine, but many of them were curving Beckham-like efforts from the sidelines.
His celebrations grew bigger with every success.
Johnathan Thurston crosses in a memorable night for the future Immortal. Source: News Corp Australia
4. ‘THAT’S FREAKISH RUGBY LEAGUE’
IT has to be in the conversation for one of the great Origin tries.
The Maroons turned on the razzle dazzle, as Cooper Cronk put in a grubber that looked to be going dead, before Justin Hodges — in his Origin finale — knocked the ball back into the in-goal for Matt Gillett to score.
Channel 9 commentator Ray Warren summed it up perfectly when he described it as “freakish rugby league”.
Watch the try in the video below
Hodges houdini act 0:55 Play video
State of Origin: Justin Hodges has left an indellible mark on his final Origin match setting up Matt Gillett for a try with some freakish work in the in-goal.
Fox Sports 08 Jul 2015 Sport/NRL/State of Origin
5. HOW DOES HE GET AWAY WITH IT?
EVERYONE knows Blues hooker Mick Ennis is one of the great nigglers in rugby league.
But just what he says to the referees was on full display on Wednesday night, when he was clearly heard sledging the whistleblower.
“You’re getting overwhelmed by the crowd, mate,” Ennis said.
Why do the refs cop that stuff?
Mick Ennis gets in the face of Justin Hodges. Source: Getty Images
6. CAM SMITH PRODUCES UNDER PRESSURE
IN the headlines all week after Alex McKinnon’s controversial interview on 60 Minutes , Cam Smith left the controversy behind to produce yet another flawless display.
Opting not to speak to Channel 9 after the final whistle, Smith finally broke his silence when he took the podium to raise the trophy for a ninth time.
“To our boys, a lot of question marks were raised over our team and our performance after game two,” Smith said.
“Looking at the scoreboard, [that] is the best way to respond.”
He later told Triple M he wanted to “have my say” on the McKinnon controversy but didn’t believe post-game was the time.
“I don’t think this is the right time to talk,” Smith said. “I’ve just finished a State of Origin game and I obviously want to enjoy this victory but I think in the near future I’ll have to come out and have my say and hopefully everyone can hear that.
“Obviously not the best of times over the last few days but I just want to concentrate on the victory tonight, I thought the guys were very good and I’m very proud of their efforts.”
Smith was also upended by Beau Scott, who will sit out one NRL match if he pleads early after being charged with a grade one dangerous throw on the Maroons skipper.
Cam Smith led from the front for Queensland. Source: News Corp Australia
7. RECORD-BREAKING NIGHT
THE 52-6 scoreline set a new mark for largest winning margin, while Thurston’s nine goals were also a new Origin record.
Cam Smith also joined Darren Lockyer as the most capped player in Origin history, playing his 36th game for the Maroons.
Greg Inglis was pretty much unstoppable. Source: Getty Images
Originally published as Shameful Blues turn Origin dirty
